>>9600431
Its cool being able to understand the references when you notice them. Curtains Down from Blood Money is a lot more satisfying when you understand the context of the scene the target is playing out, for instance.

The opera is called Tosca, and thats the ending scene. There's at least a dozen Kojima-tier absurd plot twists that precede it, but basically the character being executed believes that its a mock execution, because the chief of police pardoned him but had to keep up appearances because he's known for being tough on crime. Usually on stage, that character acts like a chad with no fear of death, and his girlfriend is singing these joking lyrics about what a good actor he is while the music itself is really tense and clues you in that he's actually fucked and the police chief didn't actually give the order to pardon. He gets shot and dies with a look of shock on his face, and his girlfriend jumps off a cliff to avoid arrest, then curtains the end.

So in a meta sense, the two targets are actually playing the roles of the two opera characters, and 47 is actually playing the role of the executioner. Tosca is pretty babbys first opera tier so its not hard to see why it'd be one they'd be looking for level material in, but the way they pulled it off is actually really impressive.

>>9608553
GameFreak was incapable of doing it and they want to keep control of the series. GF is basically an indie company that struck it big and barely knew what to do with it. By all means there should've been a console Pokemon RPG; Pokemon fans will defend it not happening but it was a wasted opportunity.
That said, Pokemon hit global saturation really late in the N64 lifespan. It reached America in September 98, but it took until 99 to really explode. By then, Gen II was about to release, Nintendo was busy with Gamecube development, and the 64DD wasted resources and time.
If Pokemon managed to stay as popular in 2001/2002(And yes, I know it was still selling millions of copies, but RS sold a little over half of what RBY did), I think there would've been a bigger push but Colosseum/Gale of Darkness shows they were considering something a bit more intricate.

I took a look into it. Panel De Pon is one of my favorite series and it's stupid I've never given PPC a chance just cause i thought it'd be a lazy game, and to your point, PPL is definitely a lazy game just using stock assets from the anime.

I get it's on a small low-res screen so they probably couldnt show the opponent screen, but this HP system seems weird and the enemies speed seems weird too. The only way I seem to win is to play slow as fuck, only do combos, no chains. If you do chains you're going to be at the bottom with nothing. This happens in PPL sometimes too if you dont stop your chains to give yourself some breathing room, but not to this degree, I think I'm actually sending no "garbage" to the enemy and it's a weird hp system.
This is not the same gameplay and this may be the worse Versus/Challenge mode i've played. Im sure every other mode is fine but this one is insanely bad..

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9603956
>It's more than just edgy dark Coldsteel the Hedgehog dark, there's a sense of rust and sinister feelings and it's all weird and I like it a lot.
I think that it does grimdark edge the right ways, it's ever present and never lets up. Every character has a strong motivation (usually vengeance for horrible wrongdoings), and just the same they are mostly very twisted and dark persons who at times are outright villainous.
They all partake in this reckless and massively destructive tournament to kill each other for the whims of someone who could just as well be the devil, and many of them will be doublecrossed if they win, said devil delighting in putting his boot on the face of people who have (relatively) noble intentions, while preferring to accommodate those who only want revenge.

Everything about the setting in Twisted Metal Black is bitter, horrible, bleak, sad, cruel, hopeless, and unfair, and it's suitable too, being that the game takes place inside of the mind of Needles Kane, aka Sweettooth. It's based on how a cynical, sadistic, and black hearted serial killer interprets the world, he sees little good in others, and he's firm in how being good never pays, how life will inevitably shit on you, or how do-gooders are secretly twisted and vile like him, he scoffs at the perceived double standards and fancies himself the only one who truly sees the world for what it is.
Might makes right to him, and since he's capable of cruel murder and can get away with it, he feels he deserves to, anyone who's a victim of anything deserves it for being weak. This all also fits with how at times, the edge is so thick and dark that it becomes comical, for Needles is a clown.

rodland. in an uncommon act of cooperation the arcade developers sent the amiga programmers the 68k source code for the arcade. one problem was that they didn't send the maps for the tile data and had to put the graphics back together again like a jigsaw. apparently the amiga developers made improvements and fixed some errors in their code while porting it and sent it back to japan.

>>9604057
I have just looked into a 30 year old game magazine. Those are the listed prices there
>Amiga 600 = 600DM (=300€)
>Amiga 1200 = 900DM (=450€)
>Amiga 2000D = 1200DM (=600€)
>Amiga 3000T = 5000DM (=2500€)
>Amiga 4000 = 4200DM (=2100€)

So the cheaper Amiga costed less than a midrange GPU does today. The Amiga 1200 is almost as good as the best models anyway.

posts.com: Commodore ended up having to outsource chip production to HP on the ECS and AGA models as their outdated facilities didn't have the capability of producing CMOS chips.

>>9609010
When the Amiga first came out in 85, it was a graphical powerhouse compared to the EGA graphics IBM just brought out the year before. But when the VGA came out in 89, it blew the Amiga's OCS right out of the water. Amiga responded with ECS in 1990, which was still inferior. Then they tried again in 92 with AGA, which was an improvement but still lacking compared to the faster 4MB VGA cards of the era. They were working on something that might have been able to compete with the Voodoo in terms of graphics, maybe, but they went bankrupt before they could finish.
Doesn't help that even the best Amiga had a stock 40Mhz 68xxx CPU in 1994, but Pentiums were hitting 100Mhz.

It was more of a testament to Motorola's failure to compete with Intel. Motorola failed to do that, even the 68000 successors failed to maintain full backwards compatibility with each other.

I have made a musical discovery regarding an old favorite: The "drugstore" (weapons, items etc) music from Earthbound is modeled on "Maxwell's Silver Hammer", by The Beatles. Although they are musically distinct, they have a clear similarity:

-Both melodies are these happy, mid-tempo, plodding but slightly subversive things.
-The pitch goes jauntily up-and-down in both cases.
-the ending of each "verse" is unmistakably the same. Try singing "sure that she was dead" to the ending of the drugstore music before it repeats again (the drugstore take adds two beats after this)
-the developers were clearly into the Beatles, per an early in-game Onett joke.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJag19WoAe0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOXFR5SQnYk

>What games in the Tales series are worth playing
You won't ever reach a consensus on this one.
Legendia is kind of a black sheep in the series, not the worst one, but it was made by a different team, so it's like a Phantasy Star III to the Tales series.

It's also worth mentioning that all the retro Tales titles were made by 2 different teams, namely team Phantasia (character design is done by Kousuke Fujishima) and team Destiny (character design is done by Mutsumi Inomata).
Each team developed somewhat of a different style through time. I usually tend to favor the team Phantasia titles (Phantasia, Synphonia, Abyss, Vesperia), although even between those titles there's one that I particularly don't like.

>>9607112
I just got finished playing AoD. I think this game was excellent when it came to the music (that main menu theme!) and the overall plot and presentation was great. Lara never looked better imo. The gameplay is what kills it. The last levels from Strahov onward are simply unfinished and cut extremely short. I would have loved to see more of that world and the stuff they would have us raid from tombs. Each classic tomb raider game really did something completely different from the last one. Collecting an Atlantean artifact from lost civilisations that developed from a cataclysm, destroying an Italian cult focussed around a Chinese dagger that turns you into a dragon hunting through sunken ships (interesting choice of tomb), Collecting meteorite splinters from all over the world for a weird social darwinist gone power-mad only to then kill him, and then a game focussed around the apocalypse being started by a haughty Lara picking up the amulet of Seth (1999 had many apocalypse plots, even V:tM Redemption), Chronicles was all over the place, and finally this weird cinematic plot of a serial killer and Icons that you need to collect and periapt shards you need to defeat the weird half-angel Nephilim race.

Tomb Raider was a wild ride. It really pisses me off that the gameplay for the final game was so piss-poor. There is lots of potential in that game and afaik they wanted to do so much more. TR Legend is just a big dumb action game with quicktime events that is over before you know it and doesn't really do anything with the king Arthur plot, not for all the dumb talking they do over it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9608128
Its the PC version of Powerslave that is a very different game and runs on the Build engine

The Saturn and PS1 versions of Powerslave are similar to each other and run on Lobotomy's own engine. The Saturn version is generally better with larger and more open levels which were cut down and changed for the PS1 version.

Powerslave Exhumed is closer to the Saturn version but includes some additional bits from the PS1 version added in to create a hybrid of the two.

James Pond is one of those European Amiga games that got console releases too.
Whenever people talk about it, it's always the second game Robocod, and I think usually the Genesis / Mega Drive version, and it's been re-released of a shitload of systems in some fashion, even Switch.

There was also an Olympics spin-off game that's often forgotten.

Also, all the covers for James Pond games always depict him holding a gun, parodying the James Bond movie posters, but I don't think he actually uses one in the games?

Setting aside that OP's point is LUDICROUSLY insipid and retarded, if his argument is that there were no resources in December 1993 to tell you about all the secrets (even if there was), then map editing software wouldn't be a counter argument, as iD never published any tools for Doom, and people had to develop that themselves.

Also, if OP is a fucking retard (and his posts strongly suggest that he is), I doubt he could navigate something like the trial version of DeepSea, or DoomCAD, because those programs weren't particularly graceful or userfriendly even for normally intelligent people, you had to just get used to the way that software sucked.

>>9596485
The grades exist to nudge you into playing the game in a way that will be more fun and skillful. It's basically an informal difficulty selection, if you're okay with getting a sub-par rank on every level the game will be easier but less satisfying, just like as if you had played on easy.

Anyway, there are benefits to being considerate about how you attack but I'll grant you don't NEED to do it to beat the game, but even so you need to do things besides button mashing to avoid damage, unless you just tank it all with items but again that's playing on babby mode and an impractical playstyle that's essentially equivalent to skipping the gameplay.

That said, I do kinda get the sense this genre pushes you much harder to learn how to properly defend than it does how to attack. Learning how to deal a lot of damage, combo, or improve your style rank/score is all a lot more optional than learning how to not get hit, and I think it can contribute to these games feeling more button-mashy on a casual level. Something that also bothers me about them is that for all the hype around sick combos, a lot of the enemies can't be meaningfully combo'd. Humanoid bosses in particular can often be stunned, allowing you to wail on them for a bit, but no matter what you do to them during these sections they just sit there: you can't move or manipulate them in any way, all you can do is deal damage. It's lame - I'm not saying you should be able to infinitely combo them, but if they're going to have a "vulnerable" state you can trigger, make them comboable when in that state.

>>9596384
Devil May Cry is considered a hack and slash game, which typically involves fast-paced, combo-based combat. The game does rely on button mashing to a certain extent, but it also requires players to master a variety of different techniques and mechanics in order to be successful. This includes mastering different weapons and abilities, juggling enemies in the air, and dodging enemy attacks.

Some players might find the game to be button-mashing, but many fans consider Devil May Cry to be a more skill-based game that requires players to master the mechanics and develop their own playstyle to truly excel.

It's also worth noting that opinions on games are subjective, some people may find the game to be too simplistic while others may think that it's deep and challenging. What is important is that you enjoy playing the game and you find it fun.

It's based on three criteria.

Time spent on the level:
Orbs obtained, hence why you need stylish to finish off enemies - they drop far more orbs if you keep combos going;
Damage received, you need to learn how enemies and bosses are designed and what patterns they use so you can safely attack them without being hit.

Also, using any items will immediately put you in a critical threshold on any of these, you're basically forced to get a perfect ranking on all of them if you want to use 1 item per level. Mission 22 is batshit insane to S rank because you can't rely on them.

Yes this is the definitive version. It vastly improves the game with new mechanics and content. It should be noted that this version alongside the All-Stars/USA version were made by Nintendo R&D2. Tanabe only directed Doki Doki Panic before it was Mario-fied. Doki Doki Panic is an inferior base game if you bother trying it out on emulator; missing crucial gameplay elements taken for granted like a run button, and bizarre, poor game design choices like forcing you to replay and beat the game as all 4 characters to reach the ending. Tanabe has always been a weak game designer even when he was young. The "respect" he mysteriously garners by pundits and ResetEra types on Twitter are misguided and misinformed.

Me personally I like the voices as a millenial Mario fan growing up during the '90s N64 era of Mario where his voice was officially instated. I figure the ones decrying it are aging Gen Xers who grew up on NES and SNES and think they're cringe/unnecessary, which is a fair opinion I guess, but to outright not play the game or say it ruins the whole entire package is elitist pedantry. The only real downside I'd say is that the color palette is too washed out for being an early GBA release with no backlight, but that's nothing a color restoration mod can't fix.

I like all versions sans Doki Doki, but if I had to choose only 1, I'll go for Advance hands down. I just don't see a point in indulging the other versions.

a 576i TV cant do 480p.
a 480p tv has 480 vertical lines, a 480i only has 240 but displays them offset from each other every other frame to create the illusion of 480 vertical lines.
a 576i screen has 288 vertical lines.
for all intents and purposes as 567i TV is functionally the same as a 480i tv, youll just have some letterboxing is all

posts.com:
>>9605507
That other anon is doing kind of a poor version of explaining it, but here is the deal:
SCART was designed to be a solution to consumer frustration with how many different signal types and connectors there need to be. Therefore, generally speaking, if a CRT has a SCART RGB input it can handle most consumer signals you throw at it.
So a PAL CRT that only handles composite for example, if you ran NTSC 60Hz into it, it might not appear correct, like it might appear black and white or not at all. But generally if you run RGB into a Scart TV, you can display NTSC 60Hz or PAL 50Hz no problem.

But idk what he means when he says RGB will always display in 60Hz, that's not true if it's a PAL 50Hz source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9607501
Games usually DON'T have any additional resolution in PAL. They're still rendered at the same internal res, then upscaled in some way.
For example PAL GTA SA on the PS2 has every fifth line doubled. It's really visible when you stand in front of CJ's house and look at the electric lines.
Some games aren't upscaled, instead the original 480 lines are drawn over 480 out of 576 lines of PAL, so you get a squished image and black bars on the top and bottom. Most older games have dogshit ports like that.
The same goes for 2D games, either upscale by doubling some lines or squish the image.
Honestly just stay away from PAL, it's a curse when it comes to retro games. I'm in Europe and the only time I'm playing a PAL version is when it's properly converted from NTSC (correct speed and good upscaling) or it has a 60Hz mode (which gives you 480i). Most EU CRTs have no problem with 60Hz, so you can use an RGB cable and just import games from Japan or NA.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9608064
That would be true for PAL video. For example a movie scanned from film and telecined into PAL would look better than the same movie telecined into NTSC (but it would be a bit faster, because 24 fps movies are sped up to 25 fps in PAL to avoid judder that's present in NTSC where the movie has to be converted to 30 fps). Or, an European TV show will usually look better than an American TV show, because it was filmed in PAL's greater resolution.
Most video games you'd want to play on a CRT were made in Japan or the US. That means they were made for NTSC's 480i/240p. In 2D games the pixel art is drawn with that resolution in mind, in 3D games there's an internal rendering resolution and it's usually the same between PAL and NTSC, with different scaling (for example many PS2 games are rendered in 512x448, in NTSC the rest are just blank lines, in PAL it has to be upscaled a bit first, and then you have the blank lines).
The point is, you won't see more detail if it isn't there in the first place. Upscaling a 480i game into 576i will only introduce artifacts (as the scale isn't integer) or blur, depending on the algorithm used.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9608064
>>9608132
>considering this image here
The image is about pixels sometimes being not square, thus allowing to fit more detail into a single line.
For example, Crash Bandicoot on the PS1 is rendered in 512x240, while Final Fantasy VII is rendered in 320x240. Both have 4:3 picture aspect ratio, in both cases the PS1 outputs 240p, the only difference being how much detail it can cram into a single line. The 512 pixels in Crash are narrower than the 320 pixels in FFVII, so the change in color and brightness can occur more often within a single line in Crash than in FFVII.
The TV doesn't really care how often something changes within a single line, as there are no pixels anymore, since we're in the analog realm. The only things it's looking for are horizontal and vertical blanking pulses, i.e. when it's got to move to the next line and the next field.
Whether your TV can actually DISPLAY all of that detail is a completely different story and there's a measurement for that. Go read up on TV lines (TVL) if you want. Higher-end CRTs like PVMs can display a lot (over 800 TVL), a shitty budget 14" TV probably won't have enough to even resolve all the detail in low-res games.

2/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You already have to realize that the PAL/NTSC standard and the 50/60hrz standard are two different things.

In the US, TVs display an image 480 lines high 60 times per second.
In Europe it is 50 images of 576 lines.
We could have had the opposite.

basically the PAL display is folds bigger than the NTSC display.
So as the US and Japanese studios didn't pay attention to PAL, they displayed the same 480 line height game on 576 line screens, so of course there are black bands!
The remaining 96 lines!!

Necessarily conversely if you import a PAL game for your NTSC console, the game will want to display its 576 lines in your 480, so the image is overwritten on your TVs.

50hrz is not slower than 60, it's less fluid.

What causes the slowness are the US/Jap studios which port to PAL, limiting themselves to displaying 60 images per second while the TVs display 50.
So result it takes 1.2 seconds to display which takes 1 second on NTSC.
To do something in 100 seconds in NTSC, it takes 120 seconds in PAL.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PGACXzEjgw4

And with this video it's the opposite problem, the guy tests a PAL and NTSC version on a console (NTSC I presume) because Codemaster is an English studio which adapted Colin McRae 2 to run at the right speed.
A CMR2 PAL on a PAL console/TV will run at the same speed as a CMR2 NTSC on an NTSC console/TV.

>>9606780
It's pretty crazy, but it seems to me once a console gets a reputation for being poorly emulated, it's VERY hard to shake that impression off. A lot of it is just most people don't actually keep up with developments and work off of whatever old assumptions and limited information they have, but N64 in particular seems to be especially bad about this. I think it probably has to do with the fact that the scene itself is pretty quiet and fragmented - it doesn't have a larger-than-life figure like byuu that constantly brought attention to all kinds of shit going on with SNES emulation AND provided a solution, nor does it have one relevant and constantly active project that puts out blog posts and shit for normies to get hyped the way Dolphin and now PCSX2 do. It had some HUGE developments in the past few years, but it was from several people working on their own solutions, not coalesced around a single end-point or project, which I guess makes it harder to reach everyone and show them the big picture. And so people might've heard there's a new plugin or two out there, but they've no clue what that actually means for the overall state of N64 emulation or whether they actually fix the numerous issues it had in the past, so for all they know, the Body Harvest bridge is still broken, you still can't play the Factor 5 games, Mario Tennis is a bugged glitchy mess, etc.

>>9608694
The "ParaLLEl" core is nothing other than the old Mupen64Plus-libretro core from around 2015 or so with the new ParaLLEl plugins (plus Angrylion) tacked on. It was rebranded as ParaLLEl-N64 to capitalize on the new ParaLLEl-RDP plugin developed by Themaister (the original creator of RetroArch), and was advertised essentially as a whole new emulator that would put all the others to shame. Unfortunately, it turns out it had a lot of latent core issues that were very hard to fix due to the current RetroArch lead dev making a ton of code changes and rewrites that made backporting fixes from upstream Mupen64Plus really hard to do. So another guy had to do a whole new fork based on the latest Mupen64Plus code with minimal changes plus the latest plugins, and so we got Mupen64Plus-Next, which is what you always want to use now. It's still apparently a touchy subject with the lead RA dev, too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Just since this is a LA thread now, as sad as it is I really like that Link is the only "real" person in the dream. Idk how it fits into the dumb timeline, but you get the sense Link is on his way to do something important before he gets shipwrecked and Koholint is just this very ideal little paradise where he could just relax instead of worrying about being a hero, but instead he chooses to try and leave and get back to heroing. Eventually he finds out that that means the other inhabitants might disappear, but from what one of the owl statues say I think it's also implied his real body is still underwater and he will drown if he chooses not to still leave. A lot of the inhabitants of the island really don't seem to have a concept of a world beyond the island, or a time before their "now". That's also why I like Marin telling Link that he has to remember her song, because in the end after Link wakes up you hear it, and I've always seen that as Link remembering her, which is what makes her real. Like a kind "all good things must come to an end" moral, like the feeling of how your hometown might not feel as homey anymore now that all this time has past and your not a kid. Be happy it happened, not sad that its over. Very melancholy (but I'm a sap who likes that kinda stuff)

I think most collectors are people who just want to play games, but are too scared (of getting arrested, of breaking their console, of dealing with any kind of technical challenge at all etc.) to figure out how to mod a console and/or run an emulator.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609141
Ive "collected" all my life, because i wanted to play all kinds of games across different platforms. I dabbled with emulation for specific platforms i didn't have hardware for(amiga, arcade), but drifted away and probably haven't bothered booting up an emulator since 2011. I only ever collected to play and i just really dont have a need to use a flashcart or emulation or modchipped system since i have mostly everything i want. Unless its some absurdly rare or unreleased game, those options just dont benefit me. As for the collecting aspect beyond playing, i just enjoy building a collection of games(more so when it was a poorfag hobby). Like, i get hating fags who buy sealed wata shit or whatever, but will never get the hateboner people have for those who enjoy both the collecting and playing aspect. Like people dont freak out on trading card collectors which is fairly comparable as having a use beyond mere collecting. If you just want to play the roms, cool, but there is a fun aspect of building a collection as well, just like stamps or coins or whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609124
Obviously both types exist. For a lot of people (myself included) a collection is just a library of games that they want to play. I have 500+ games and I'm always playing something, but obviously I can't play every single game every single day so most of them will actually sit on the shelf collecting dust until I decide to revisit them. But the alternative would be to have a small collection and play the same 10 games over and over and over. I certainly do love revisiting games - and I have favorites that I revisit more than others - but I also like picking up games that I've never played before and adding them to the library. Playing the same handful of games all the time would get boring. Also I have kids and the oldest is at the age where he's starting to become able to play games and he has expressed an interest in my collection, so of course I'm going to be playing through a lot of these games with him also.

I have some boxed games. For those, I take the cart out of the box and put it in with the rest of my library. But the box does get displayed on a shelf. You can call it dust collecting if you want but it's only for select favorite games, and the shelf is actually a display case so there's no dust.

But there are also people who go for complete libraries and there's no way that they're playing everything because a lot of games are literally unplayable garbage. Like are you really playing that Barbie game or are you just hoarding it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609152
It's like books. Sure if you just want to read then you could read an ebook on your phone or a kindle, but there's no denying that having a collection of actual books is just better. If you talk to book lovers most of them dabble with ebooks but also have a collection of physical books that they love and of course they're not reading them every single day. Most game collectors are no different. As I mentioned in my other comment I have hundreds of games across various consoles and handhelds, but I also dabble with emulation a bit (I love my Retroid) and I have flash carts or ODE's for most of my systems. But the real thing is always a better experience. I would rather PLAY the game than spend most of my time adjusting emulator settings trying to get everything just right, and while flash carts are nice for whatever reason I'm more likely to invest time into games that I actually own (I think it's a "freedom of choice" problem). But just because I own real hardware doesn't mean that I don't know what the experience of other options is like. Before I started building up my library I exclusively emulated and during that time I always wanted a real collection so that I wouldn't have to deal with the very-real emulator jank that a lot of emufags are in denial about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590467
Tiger-Heli is probably the best beginner shmup there is as it forces you to learn all of the basics to complete it without dying, and also has very forgiving checkpoints. Ideally, you want to practice sections without dying though, as you can just brute-force through sections with dying.

It's just a very basic game that beginners would probably find too primitive/boring, and the main flaw is just that the terrain and enemies are so limited that it's hard to actually know/memorize which section you're at because it all flows together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590227
All depend on what you are looking for.

Any shmup can be your first it really, depend on the dedication you want to poor on it, even more true when nowdays you have training tools, adjustable auto fire,rewind and save states which make the training way more efficient and short.

Also be aware that some games can be average to hard to 1CC but very hard to insane 2ALL ( 2nd Loop), some Psikyo games are like this for example.

Now for the recommendation I try to give you some easily emulated or game available on steam or ACA :
Relatively easy.
Dariusburst AC : depend on the route but it mostly easy/mild hard at best for an 1CC)
Akai Katana got released last month it's a mild difficulty cave with a lot of thing to learn from.
Area 88 is fun arcade game you may learn movement and placement, learning curve is kind of flat but expect a small pick at level 5. give the snes/sfc version a try too.

Normal
R-type leo is kind of the same you may also learn some stuff about force and option (harder at level 4).
Fighting Hawk is close to Area 88 but as a verti. not too hard not too easy
Metal Black is between the 2 but you won't learn that much from as the game is weird AF.
some others weird shmup ; fun but wont learn much from them.
Xexex mild 1CC on the japanese version. (2all is another story)
X-Multiply is slightly harder to 1CC but at least you won't have a burnout dealing with it 2ALL even if it's hard.

Mild hard
Game Tengoku is cute nice and fun and you will learn tons of shit and tricks, but 2ALL is on another story, way too hard for it own good.
Dragon Spirit is old but it one of my favorite games ever, it come from a time where you needed a separate button to shoot sol enemies. Maybe a little bit long and learning curve can be a bitch.
Outzone depend on the version and weapon management can be a nice game to pick.

Also most Psikyo and Cave games 1CC can be put here.

Absolutely. The point of a singleplayer game is to have a fun experience.

posts.com:
>>9599203
>For games that have mechanics like these, do you make an effort to actually use them...
Yes. Even Duke Nukem 3D has the Mighty Boot, which is tremendously useful, not just for breaking and activating this or that without, but it helps for close combat fighting. When you've got just your pistol, you can combine its rapid fire with you getting right up in the enemy's face and repeatedly kicking them in the jaw as you pump them full of lead, back off shortly as they try to wind up retaliatory attacks and then get up close, and you can stunlock some enemies with decent reliability, particularly Octabrains. Can be done with the Shotgun and Chaingun but typically aren't as critical given their reliable stunning, though it can pay off.

Haven't tried this much with Pig Cops or Assault Troopers because their hitscans fucking hurt and it's better to prioritize making yourself a smaller and/or more distant target, finding cover, or strafing (because their aim actually doesn't have perfect followthrough like in Doom). Have done it in desperation when cornered by Protector Drones, but MAN is it intense, they're fast and jumpy, their melee is mean, and their shrink ray is devilish.

>... or do you just play every game like you would play Doom, just running and gunning?
Funny you bring it up. I play Doom in basically two ways, more vanilla(ish) ways, with no freelook or any such thing, and then with GzDoom, which may or may not involve gameplay mods, but just the same allows for full freelook, jumping, crouching, completed Z-Axis collisions, etc, and it's fun to use all that for combat mobility like I'm playing Duke or Half-Life, I just enjoy it a lot and it has its uses. If a Revenant opens up on you, you can rush forward and crouch at the same time so his rocket sails over your head, and you can keep shooting or then fall back as needed, whatever is suitable.

I'm mostly conscious to not break level sequencing though, not getting to places I haven't unlocked, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9605260
Sure, but they remain roughly about as relevant as in most of their history. WW1 is more an outlier in heavier bayonet usage, due to being a massive industrially backed war where equipment and tactics hadn't caught up with a lot of new technology (mostly for some very stupid reasons, there was a lot which was telling of where things were going many years in advance).
For most of their history bayonets were used kind of seldom, to the point that there genuinely existed a sentiment in the later 1800s and in the 1900s that they were obsolete. With better options for intense close quarters combat coming around in WW1 and the interwar period, use goes back down to more normal levels, but it never disappears. Bayonet charges specifically occur sporadically in warfare, from the rest of the 20th century up to today, and they can be really helpful at times, even modern armies engage in them. It's actually fairly consistent with older times.
With the Cold War, we all just arrived at the most practical approach where the bayonet is the soldier's general utility knife, used for all sorts of not-combat stuff 95% of the time, but which is designed so that you can it attach to the end of your rifle and then use it for pokey times when that's a good idea (which IS seldom, but not never).

WW1 would be a viable setting for a lot of bayonet focused combat, but you wouldn't have to restrain yourself to that, you can have bayonets in your shooting games just because it's cool, it's not like you're doing a realistic depiction of warfare anyway, you're usually the one man army.

Christopher was always intended to be Simon's ancestor. He's explicitly name-dropped in the original Japanese manual as the Belmont that destroyed Dracula many years ago. Supposedly (not -100%- confirmed last I checked but anecdotally), the reason Trevor's name is Ralph C. in Japan is because it's a remnant of when Castlevania III was going to detail Christopher's story, but then a Game Boy game beat them to it and they could no longer do that reveal. I think the question of whether The Adventure or III took place first was put off for a while until Konami started sharing the series timeline publicly, and they decided on III being first and I guess implied that Christopher took after Ralph/Trevor's middle name.

video_crf = 18
video_preset = superfast
video_tune = animation
audio_bit_rate = 320000
sample_rate = 44100
format = matroska

2) Boot RetroArch

3) Settings > Recording > Set 'Recording Quality' to 'Custom'

4) Settings > Recording > As 'Custom Record Configuration' select 'Custom.cfg' from step 1)

5) Optional: Settings > Recording > Set 'Use GPU Recording' to 'On' if you want to record video after shaders and scaling have been applied - which is not a good idea if the purpose of the recording is to post WebMs on 4chan. File size is too small > image quality too low. (Warning: This is resource intensive and I recommend you leave it turned off.)

6) Settings > Input > Hotkey Binds > Set 'Recording Toggle' to any key / button you like or start and stop the recording process from the Quick Menu. (You also set a custom directory for saving the recordings, standard will be *\recordings in your RetroArch installation

If your PC is really beefy you can also try the following preset instead of normal.cfg and call that lossless.cfg. A word of warning though, the resulting files will be huge
ormat = matroska
threads = 3
vcodec = libx264rgb
video_tune = animation
pix_fmt = bgr24
video_qp = 0
acodec = flac

>This confuses and enrages the video game preservationist

Now now, I'll just be up front. There's obviously very little inherent worth in archiving the creations of 11 year old dipshits, but can we be honest with each other? GameMaker titles number well into the six digits, and yet people only seem to have awareness of CrimeLife 2 and Undertale. Maybe a couple Mario & Sonic fangames.

If people are so gosh darn intent on keeping the memory of literal who PC games alive from every era of the Internet, including Adobe Flash, where is the love and respect for YoYoGames?

Mark my words, in about 10 years there's going to be a problem. With sites like Itch.io and GameJolt having such a young userbase, barely anyone will do the necessary work and have functional databases for these games.

https://www.yygarchive.org/

Sure, this exists, but look at how barren and clinical it is. The fact of the matter is, nobody knows what the fuck to do with the veritable onslaught of low-quality, yet potentially invaluable slop zoomers and millennials vomited up in the 2000s. In a decade, will there be a comprehensive catalog of each and every FNaF clone ever made, regardless of its quality? Will we see a crisis as Friday Night Funkin mods become spread thinner and thinner across obscure Discord channels? Methinks people should spend less time worrying about hardware restoration and translating PC-98 games, and focus more on games that are uploaded today and could disappear tomorrow. But that's just me.

>>9606612
Here's my overview of the series as it stands in 2023

SMT5 is the most approachable one just because of how many QoL features are shoved into it (like compendium fusion) and the fact that you can avoid battles whenever you want
SMT3 is the one I started with, it can be really unforgiving at times but it's phenomenal. The HD remaster is fine (it's lazy) but it adds a major QoL feature during fusion that doesn't make the game easier but saves a bunch of time
SMT4 is known mostly just for being the easiest mainline entry and having a totally retarded true ending path, but its still good. SMT4A is worth playing if you liked SMT4 just because the core gameplay is even better, even if everything else is retarded
SMT Strange Journey is excellent as well but imo it's not the best place to start. It's more in line with "classic" SMT. But it's really great.

SMT1 is probably not the best place to start imo, but the new PS1 translation is the way to go for this one
SMT2 is definitely not the best place to start imo, probably the worst of all mainline...

SMT If... is considered the proto-Persona, it is extremely polished for a Super Famicom RPG. There's also a PSX version with an easier difficulty but i dont think this is translated...
The Persona games are also worth a look, I would probably start with Persona 4 (P4G is fine too if that's easier to access now). Persona 5 Royal is easily the most braindead easy game in the entire megaten franchise so that's the easy recommendation for someone who is totally unfamiliar with JRPGS and the series at large. Despite it being piss easy it has a lot to offer in terms of presentation style stuff.

Finally there are dozens of spinoffs, but the one I would recommend first and foremost is Devil Survivor.

Sorry for rambling but I would say if you are experienced with JRPGs I would go SMT3 > SMT If... > SMT5 > Persona4 but there are genuinely no wrong answers aside from starting with SMT2

Have fun!

>>9606812
Zelda 1 has better exploration thanks to its more open, more detailed world
both Zeldas have more interesting combat thanks to the relative weakness of Link's abilities (Crystalis guy is super agile, has endless powerful projectiles with knockback) and a far greater variety of enemy behaviors and abilities (this is a big one; Crystalis monsters usually just walk toward you like chumps)
both Zeldas have more interesting level design; Crystalis has okay caves/dungeons/etc. but they're mainly just mazes without puzzles or gimmicks or anything and are almost all similar to one another (Zelda 1 puzzles are crude yes, but they're better than NO puzzles)
Crystalis has fun sword attacks, a better story and more interesting world, a better soundtrack, more bosses, better story-related puzzles (to balance the lack of room-to-room puzzles in dungeons), better items than Zelda 2 (maybe not Zelda 1 though), better spells than Zelda 2, and more talking rabbits
I dunno that's what I came up with just now, deeper analysis would yield something different

>level names were conceived to be food puns ala Kirby's Adventure
>R2 just so happens to use an alliterative name
>some dev pointed that out and the team like it enough to rename the other levels
>Ridicule Root was renamed to Dangerous Depths after the food theming was removed
I'm not sure where Crazy Toy Box fits in, though. There could've been a third set of level names at some point that were neither food-related nor alliteration. It also seems like R2 was either removed or unimplemented by the time of the Ver0.02 proto with Salad Plain, so DD had to be VERY shortlived compared to RR: https://forums.sonicretro.org/index.php?threads/sonic-cds-mysterious-cut-r2-level-discussion-post-origins-edition.41136/page-11#post-1032578
Either way, I'm glad we don't have to call it "R2" anymore, because that also refers to Desert Dazzle, the R2 replacement Taxman conceived of that eventually became Mania's Mirage Saloon. I motion for Ridicule Root because it seems the level was probably known by that name longer and the abbreviation is less confused with Desert Dazzle. What I want to know ultimately is: in what way was this level apparently worse than Wacky Workbench?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592669
In each level, you drive around the area with your tank, finding dungeons to enter on foot.
Most of those dungeons are optional, but important so you can upgrade your gun. Although you can very well just find a good place to grind your gun, go back&forth, and then be on your way.
One of the dungeons in each level has a boss which gives you an upgrade for the tank (like a new weapon or hover or driving on walls etc), necessary to unlock the path to the next level, and so on.

You can strafe by holding the bomb button.
Try to always have your gun max'd out before a boss, I know it's not easy. Some higher gun levels are actually shittier than earlier ones too because of poor hit detection. If all else fails, find a good spot to spam grenade on a boss.

Other protips: some of the levels loop on themselves, or have shortcuts that teleport you to another area. It makes some levels more confusing than they should be (level 2 is actually the worse)
You only have 3 lives, 4 continues. Infinite continues in the JPN version. It's actually pretty hard to beat the game in 4 continues, you have to know where to go, I only did it after beating the JPN version.
At some point once you get a certain upgrade, you'll find there is nowhere to go with the tank. You have to think Metroid and backtrack to an earlier level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590638
Honestly play both (specifically OG Metafight for >>9590696 reasons). Blaster Master Zero gives you the outward impression of being a stright remake of the first game with its opening area and returning enemies, but then it throws a curveball and the series turns out to be a brilliantly subverted Metafight sequel.
...Oh, you wanted to dabble in the older sequels? Don't. The series was passed around Z-teams and didn't go anywhere until Zero, so you're better off ignoring them. The PlayStation game may be worth checking out if you want some context for a few story elements in Zero 2&3, and MAYBE try the GBC one if you just want more BM-otherwise, do yourself a favor and avoid the Western-made shovelware.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9603609
>Skele-venom as the Plutonium Boss
There's really no indication this was ever true back in the day. Sunsoft's official mag had this to say instead:
>Be on your toes to avoid the Plutonium Boss's whip.[...]the little creep is dog-meat.
Which sounds an awful lot like it's describing GOEZ and not the penultimate boss (it could also be interpreting both bosses as two forms of the same being since it doesn't mention fighting his "dog"). What probably happened is that kids assumed the creature shown on the cover is the main villain, and eventually enough people online rolled with it.
>Then what about Zero's Skeleton Boss?
Literally Skele-venom, as proven when you set the game to Japanese. For some asinine reason, the Zero and Zero 2 localizers decided to rename all the boss enemies in other language settings to fit what they thought was Blaster Master canon, but all they did was look up unsourced wiki names and assume they must've had it right. They can be traced to a fan-walkthrough by Dingo Jellybean. They renamed the returning frog boss because most people who played the game assumed it was the frog from the intro, even though the magazine and novelization suggest it's something else and the ending shows Fred unharmed. This also causes a translation issue with the Underworld Lord by Zero 3. Jason by all accounts should've known what its name was, but because they fucked up in Zero 1, localization halfasses it by claiming GOEZ is the Underworld Lord's name on planet Sophia, which makes -no- sense because the name was displayed by the namesake tank's -Sophian- records. So why did Jason get another name? Was it stuck on auto-translate? But that can't be, because as we all know, humanoids speak the same language in the future. Also, Eve was able to retrieve the actual name of the mutants in optional dialog (Invem), although it wasn't revealed yet to keep the Metafight aspect a surprise. Needless to say, Japanese text doesn't have this avoidable plothole.

The fact is, as old info withers away and the old guard of creatives inevitably go, you're going to see more of this happen over time. Not just in the West, but Japan is starting to do this as well, like that time Smash Bros. recited a Japanese Wikipedia article for a list of Piranha Plants or when NoJ allowed NintendoDream fan-mag writers to officialize their theories to fill in some Zelda lore-gaps in Hyrule Encyclopedia (not to be confused with Historia). You should see the Dark Horse game encyclopedias over at archive.org, they're a shitshow if you know what to look out for (there's a certain name that keeps popping up in them too, so signs point to him being the one responsible for most of it, but he probably won't ever get criticized too harshly since he became a somewhat respectable game writer and seems like a nice chap personally, he just leans way too heavily at fandom nods). Mario Wiki put up a vigilant fight (I think it helped that they took a page from the Transformers wiki and basically told canonfags to go fuck themselves early on when the mental adolescents over at other wikis were obsessing over it), but they recently made a "well, if they're sticking with their guns with some of this crap, I guess our hands are tied" concession, which I fear is going to backfire and send the wrong message.

posts.com:
I couldn't find a 1CC thread in the catalog, so here it is. 1CC stands for one credit clear, usually being used to describe arcades, so completing a video game without using a single continue, though its meaning can vary depending on what you're playing, for example when regarding consoles, the concept of credits isn't really identical to how it is in arcades, so many consider a console 1CC to be a completion without losing a single life, instead of simply not using continues, though opinions may differ, and some still consider a console 1CC to also be a matter of simply not using continues at all instead.

>What 1CC are you currently working on?
>What's the latest 1CC you've managed to get?
>Which 1CC of yours are you most proud of getting?
>How do you perceive console 1CCs to differ from arcade?

I struggle a little with 1CCs, as I do love the idea, that of mastering whatever you're playing completely, which is what it takes to even stand a chance, but it can definitely be a shame to be on a good run only for it to go to waste near the end. I personally consider a console 1CC to be a perfect run, not losing a single life, unless we're talking about arcades, which is where this idea originated from, and with that in mind my proudest 1CC is probably Sonic the Hedgehog, the original SEGA Mega Drive classic, I grew up with it, so getting a 1CC, and with 100% completion too, was both fun and special to me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9607195
Can't help you much without a replay of yours, but:
Use C-Shot, probably the best for a clear (better than C-L because of the power down after death). But if you're more comfortable with the A type go with that. B is kinda tricky but perfectly usable.
Don't be afraid to move up, as you deal more damage if you're close to an enemy. It's the only way to deal with the 2 last stages without bombing too much. With C-S, being near the top of the screen and spamming your regular shot (not the laser) will destroy so much stuff before they even fire (works great against the "needle" enemies in Stage 3 for example).
Learn how to get the extend in the 3rd stage if you don't know already.
Just bomb a lot, you get more than 30 bombs for a loop, you should be able to skip a lot of hard stuff this way.
There's a trick to "skip" the second half of the 4th boss which you can see in some replays, but I find it hard to setup (and even good players mess it up sometimes), honestly for a scrub 1cc just bomb during the second half if you get cornered, and focus on learning the rest of the game. It's only useful if playing for score.
And the usual "learn where dangerous enemies spawn so you can kill them before they even fire", as it's extremely important in CAVE games. You don't have to bother with that for the first 3 stages, but you'll need it for the second half.

>>9607543
GaiaSeed on the PS1 is a really cool game whose only flaw is that it's too easy. Give it some love.
Harmful Park (also on the PS1) has more challenge and depth of strategy, but is still easy *once* you've found the correct strategy.
Darius Gaiden with autofire is easy enough while still counting as an "adult's" shmup. Enjoy the trippy space fish aesthetic.

But keep in mind that people (very good players even) play some shmups for years and years while never getting the 1CC, and blindly focusing on those may not be a sound way to enjoy these games.

Also...
>Japanese/USA 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 N64 releases are alternatively known as NTSC 1.0, NTSC 1.1, and NTSC 1.2 respectively. Although they are technically different binaries, the only difference between the two is the country code byte in the ROM header, which is used to set the ROM's default language. There is no in-game language selection feature.

Wait, so the entire game is in both Japanese and English on all NTSC versions? But instead of having a language select... they hard-code which language the game will use? That, yeah, that sounds like a perfectly Nintendo thing to do. I would have assumed this was a cheap attempt at trying to region lock/discourage imports, but they already had a (pathetically easy to overcome) region lock on the N64 AND the game released with only a two-day difference between Japan and the US (Not like YouTube or Twitch was a thing back then and importing would have taken longer than two days) so there was zero point if that was the reason.

>>9605195
That sounds like a pretty shitty deal even for 2012, yeah. Retro overpricing was heavily ramping up by then.

I sold just the BOXES for some of my old consoles and N64 games for several hundred altogether. In fact, I sold some of the extra consoles I had lying around that I no longer need and they went for much less than the empty boxes, unless it's a more recent console.

I was never much of a collector, at most I like to collect some of the more noteworthy games or ones from the past that I just really liked but I never cared too much about the boxes or condition over just playing the games. I have no desire to have a "full collection" for a console like some have, at least, not in physical form. I lucked out a bit though, went on a spending spree for old N64 and PS1 games around 2006, a little before the retro-boom. I remember it being considered expensive to pay more than $10 for a PS1 or N64 game that wasn't something rare, Amazon was full of hundreds of sealed boxed copies of Perfect Dark for $3 each. Managed to snag dozens of the N64 and PS1 games I always wanted to play, or had rented and loved but never owned for $1-5 each. Even ones that are expensive nowadays like Conker, the Banjo games, 007, every WWF game, Yoshi's Story, Mystical Ninja, Bomberman, and a few others... sadly I think I didn't get Diddy Kong Racing or the Turok games. Most are just the cart, but a few like Conker are CIB... that have actually degraded a bit because I had no idea I should have stored them well at the time.

That being said a few are special to me, such as a copy of Megaman 1 complete in box that I got for a mere 25 cents at a garage sale less than a year ago. I was very very tempted to sell it since that tends to go for over $300, but I wanted to just have at least one thing special since as far as I am aware nothing in my entire game collection since I started gaming in the NES era is special or rare and decided to keep it.

(Also, WATA can go burn in hell)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Samurai Shodown was a huge hit when it came out. It was probably the best looking fighting game at that time and nothing else had its theme.
Also it was fun and described as 'Fuckin rad' by most of the dudes who played it.
Honestly it was exactly what was needed in fighters at the time. A game that was two things at once:
>Good
and
>Significantly different to Street Fighter
I can't overstate the latter. It didn't look like street fighter and it didn't play like street fighter. So when the main game (as SF was at the time) started to drag on your youl could have a samurai excursion. Some stayed there.
The latter, the fact that its good, is kind of what held Mortal Kombat back. It didn't look or play like SF either but it was harder to stick to once you'd seen its gimmicks. I think MK is more apt to be called style over substance; but its style really was something all the same.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9607003
>>9607052
Long and difficult to execute combos create a skill differential.
The longer you invest in execution, the higher your chances of dealing high damage and finally winning the match.
Take that option away from fighting games and what you get is Street Fighter V, a game where ideal (top) punishes are so easy (for fighting game addicts at least) that you can't even have an executional advantage over your oponent, turning the gameplay into a mere rock paper scissors match.
You knock the oponent down, you force him to guess, whoever guesses wrong 3 times loses the round.
Take KoF 98 or in the modern age, DBFZ, for example.
You still have that guessing game going on, but if a guy can REALLY execute hardass combos that he spent hundreds of hours practicing, he'll win every single match because he worked his ass off towards dishing out more damage.
>tldr
Call skill autism all you want, good competitive games reward hard work and that's how it should be

>>9570704
I'm not sure what you mean.
Each flipper is either activated or not at any one instant, but there are some techniques where quick presses matter, like pic related.

The important techniques of pinball are divided into:

Aiming
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ch7H19SHkXE
Nudging
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xeRcCbNNTeU
And ball control
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s_h0FPhjuaI

See here for a list of techniques:
https://www.deadflip.com/tutorials

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571254
If you hold the left flipper on the plunge you can go for a super skillshot, which may have a better feed to the flippers. If you don't understand what I'm talking about, here:

http://pinball.org/rules/medievalmadness.html

>>9571268
It's actually called nudging, not tilting. Nudging is nudging, tilting is when you nudge too much.
There's also flipper skills, if you don't want to learn how to nudge you can lengthen your ball times a lot with just aiming and ball control stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
HOW TO GET GOOD AT PINBALL (optional, but helpful for getting more gametime for your quarters)

How to find pinball and pinball tournaments in your area:
US, Canada, Australia, Japan, Finland, UK
https://pinballmap.com/
Worldwide:
https://pinside.com/pinball/map
Europe:
https://findapinball.com/en/browse/

Tournaments:
Depending on where you live, there may be a facebook group for players in your area.
You can also find tournaments near you here and here:
https://www.ifpapinball.com/calendar/
https://matchplay.events/live

Pinball Simulators that will give you a free virtual pin or two as a sample:
Pinball Fx 3 (Sorcerer's Lair, Fish Tales)
Zaccaria (Time Machine)
Pinball Arcade (Varies weekly or something)
There's also Visual Pinball, which is a freeware pinball simulator.

How to become Good at Pinball (wholly optional):
https://www.deadflip.com/tutorials/ (techniques in gif form)
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL-WQLGFMr97DnxeE1Rmi-wAwa-Vm7D-7i

There are many scam pinball retailer websites. See here for more information:
https://pinside.com/pinball/forum/topic/beware-of-scam-game-seller-websites

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9578523
Yup, innovations tend to fail.
While some wanted pinballs as wide as pool table, Lawlor created a mini-pinball, with a goose game on the front panel. It was time-based: you had no balls limit, the game would keep giving it back to you until you ran out of time, and you had to complete objectives to get extra time. It was really fun, and it completely failed.

posts.name: Anonymous

The somewhat rare Jersey Jack Pinball Pirates of the Caribbean pinball machine also has a cannon. You shoot the ball onto the mini-playfield pirate ship that rocks back and forth, and then you load the ball into the cannon. >>9579687
>Can I plug them in?
Why, yes. Especially if you're looking for an alternative way to heat your home.
>Will such old machines have problems if I just plug them back in after many years or not being used?
Probably. But there are just a couple of things to check. Remove the backglass, open the front panel, and find the batteries. Acid is most likely leaking from them straight down on the motherboard.
Also check out the fuses (also in the panel). Just make sure they all work, if needed replace them BUT respect the manual. Don't put slow blow in fast blow and vice versace.
>What would be the best way to sell them?
Keep them.

https://pinside.com/pinball/forum/topic/varkon-club/page/3#post-6628631

Found this post saying he was offered 20k for a restored Varkon (aka a Varkon in very good condition), so 10K for a bad one seems increasingly possible.
The hype thing with sealed videogames is sort of a separate issue from anything going on with pinball. The arcade buying world and the collectible videogame buying world are two different worlds. Even the arcade world and pinball world are kind of different.

There was a pinball auction in California that was covered in the NYT where a bunch of pins were sold to various uninformed people on the internet for way more than they would typically go for, but that's just typical for any auction, I think. But aside from that, new and used pinball prices have been going up, and not in any illusory way.

Part of the reason Varkon is valuable, apart from rarity, is that people like the gameplay and theme. There are a lot of rare games that are not that valuable because people don't care for the gameplay/theme.

The true number of Varkons that exist is probably less than 90 btw, since some of them were converted into arcade (videogame) cabinets. And of course, some of them were probably scrapped.

>>9581778
It's a reasonable choice for number 1, I'd say. It's by Keith Elwin, who was the greatest pinball tournament player for longer than anyone and now is an extremely popular pinball designer. And Godzilla is his most recent game, and it's seemingly universally liked by everyone.

As for what's so good about it:
The playfield is innovative, and the experiment is successful, I'd say. Lots of careful attention paid to geometry. Some interesting stuff that's either never been done before or hasn't been done in this way.
The code is good. Lots of breadth and depth. Not sure what else to say about it, other than that it's full of clever original wrinkles like a lot of other games (particularly Elwin games maybe), but moreso.
People like the theme. As do I.

>is Godzilla really worthy of being Ranked 1st?
No
Here's how Pinside's Top 100 works; people buy new Stern machine, out of obligation or guilt or whatever the fuck the owners of new Stern machine (that they paid thousands of dollars for) rank their expensive new toy the best thing ever.
Over time and with normal pinball players giving realistic rankings and pinball owners ranking their newer Stern machines higher the newer Stern machine outranks it, wash and repeat.
12 of the top 20 tables on Pinside were released in the last decade. It's like that bullshit about Black Panther being one of the highest rated movies of all time, it's bullshit bias and agenda.

The underlying reality is that pinball machines were designed to steal quarters from kids much like slots from adults, and that kids would use nudging to stay in the game. They added tilt to prevent this and keep the quarter stealing going. When they started making tables for home use, quarter stealing became less of a design focus, but nudging stayed. Personally, I don't really nudge because I think the game is more fun when your skill should solely come from being able to manage the ball with flippers, but I understand why people nudge because its inherent in the nature of a physical game like pinball.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9591112
You seem to be misunderstanding something. Nudging is not something the general public does to machines. It's someone only very specific players do. And Nudging, shifting, or moving the machine *will* cause issues over time. They loosen screws, bolts, and wear out the machine connections at joints. It's a physical movement of the machine afterall. Maybe not cause issues right away, but it will over time.

I've even seen instances where a player nudges too hard and can cause cracks in the glass. Do these people take responsibility? Nope. They just quietly walk away and leave the arcade without saying anything. Now the arcade owner has to pay to replace the glass. And the pinball is now out of service for days or weeks depending on how quickly they replace the glass.

Nudging (or any other "pro" pinball techniques) causes problems over time when a single player does it. Now imagine a pinball machine in a public arcade. It gets played dozens of times a day by many different players. More if it's popular location. It wears out the machine faster. Pins are just pieces of wood and metal after all. It's gonna break eventually if you keep stressing the connection points with movement.

You might be able to get away with it with newer machines but These older pinball machines aren't made anymore and sourcing replacement parts are difficult if something serious breaks. They should be respected and treated with an extra level of care from players if it's an older machine. This isn't the 1980s or 1990s anymore. These machines are old now.


Personally, I'd much rather focus on flipper control than worry about nudging and shifting a machine. If I have to nudge then it means I took a bad shot and misjudged the ball angle. A nudge is like admitting I failed.

It appears I dont remember, whats a pinball?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9593672
>Pinball games are a family of games in which a ball is propelled into a specially designed table where it bounces off various obstacles, scoring points either en route or when it comes to rest. Historically the board was studded with nails called 'pins' and had hollows or pockets which scored points if the ball came to rest in them. Today, pinball is most commonly an arcade game in which the ball is fired into a specially designed cabinet known as a pinball machine, hitting various lights, bumpers, ramps, and other targets depending on its design. The game's object is generally to score as many points as possible by hitting these targets and making various shots with flippers before the ball is lost. Most pinball machines use one ball per turn (except during special multi-ball phases), and the game ends when the ball(s) from the last turn are lost.

>For the nudge, no nudge argument i do think nudging is completely viable
The problem is that the argument is based on:

"I will do whatever it takes to win. I don't care or give af."

Your starting point for the argument is that "you want to win" . So your whole argument is just logical fallacies and justifications on why your questionable actions should be allowed.

But your starting point should be "I should respect the machine and not abuse it".
That should be the starting point for everything. Because if you break it, then you are responsible.

>and if it takes 15 years for the leg to not work anymore and require repairs that is a testament to build quality of machines.

This makes no sense. First of all Most pinball machines are not brand new. Are you going to pay for the damage caused if you "nudge" a machine and (that rare situation happens) the leg gives out? Or if you crack the glass?

Let me also add there is no defined version of "nudging". Movement that might be acceptable to you might be completely understandable to the pinball machine owner.

Other anon said he saw someone lift and slam a pinball machine and called it nudging. Tournaments can get heated too. These pinball machines are Electro-Mechanical machines. Not arcade machines. That means abuse will knock things out of alignment or calibration over time.

>But if the games themselves by design allow you to nudge to a certian degree before it locks up, wouldnt that be encouraging the mechanic as a risk/reward system?

I don't think you understand what "by design" means. Pinball Manufacturers have never promoted moving the machine during play.

Manufacturers noticed people were physical shaking, lifting, and slamming the machine to keep their ball alive. The tilt mechanism was added as a "penalty" for the players.

The tilt mechanism was NOT added as a "challenge" to players. They aren't challenging players to 'see how much they can shake the machine without triggering tilt'.

Usually there is a clear difference between nudging and straight up abusing the machine. Slapping the sides does not equal picking it up. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597367

>But if the games themselves by design allow you to nudge to a certian degree before it locks up, wouldnt that be encouraging the mechanic as a risk/reward system?

I don't think you understand what "by design" means. Pinball Manufacturers have never promoted moving the machine during play.

Manufacturers noticed people were physical shaking, lifting, and slamming the machine to keep their ball alive. The tilt mechanism was added as a "penalty" for the players.

The tilt mechanism was NOT added as a "challenge" to players. They aren't challenging players to 'see how much they can shake the machine without triggering tilt'.

Giving the player tilt warnings promotes nudging. Some machines replenish players tilt warnings, which promotes nudging.
Example:
Total Nuclear Annihilation gives more tilt warnings for a mystery award.
Jersey Jack's Pirates of the Caribbean lets you gamble tilt warnings to get more in Liar's Dice.
There are probably more I've forgotten.

Also JJP Pirates of the Caribbean has an "escape the locker" hole on the right outlane going to the shooter lane where you can nudge to save your ball. And a crossover return lane.

A lot of machines have unique outlanes that are designed to give you an extra opportunity to save your ball through nudging. Although they do occasionally give you your ball back without nudging, the designers clearly intended them to be used with nudging.

Centaur, Skateball, Full Throttle, Alien, Wheel of Fortune, etcetera.

>>9601176
>Don't fall the pinmeme prices. Go for 3k max.

This 100%. I think a lot of people need to understand this. There is a big difference between:

"Collector value" - (the highest price that investors and scalpers hope you to pay)

VS

"Street value" - (the price range that most players are willing to realistically pay)

Anyone can setup a website, hype up prices, and claim something is worth X amount. But is anyone actually going to pay it? Doubtful.

Hercules is a huge machine. The gimmick is that it's huge and biggest official pinball in the world. Buts it's quite boring to play. Everything moves slowly. The machine also needs to be serviced regularly to keep it running. It is notorious for being temperamental and breaking down over the smallest things.

The Hercules anon described has been sitting in garage for who knows how long. It doesn't turn on. The sound doesn't work. And it hasnt been serviced in at least a decade or two. It needs a lot of work to get it running again.

Unless you love Hercules and want to collect it for sentimental reasons, then I would pass at $6K. Personally I wouldn't offer more than $2K and that's my max.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600930
To be fair, DX Sonic has a much higher polygon count than the DC version, but I agree that people overblow how "weak" the DC was. People forget that the DC can run most of its library in 480p, while the PS2 can mostly just manage to hit 480i (which is really just 240p but doubled). In truth, all the killer apps for all of the consoles of the time were highly specialized to the hardware they were built for, hence why most DC ports look dramatically worse on PS2, or sound better than on the GC. The DC definitely couldnt run the post-processing effects of SH2, but I don't think the texture work would be impossible as the DC has texture decompression, while the PS2 doesn't. I really think we never saw what the DC was completely capable of as a lot of techniques were developed later in the gen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592276
>>9592278
You don't need a FX2 chip. All the FX2 did was support larger ROMs than the FX1, the FX1 otherwise performs the same as the FX2. Many people assumed the FX1 runs slower from trying to use Star Fox 1 as the doner cart, but the chip used in Star Fox 1 was slower variant called the Mario Chip. The ROM of Star Fox 2 is small enough to be fully addressable with the FX1. The most likely reason that Star Fox 2 was going to use a FX2 chip is that they were probably not producing the FX1 anymore, not that it needed it. Even if the FX2 cost more to make, having production of both FX1 and FX2 going on at the same time when any FX1 game would run the same on a FX2 would have cost more.

There are far less games that had a FX2 in them, and even less that had battery SRAM. About your only option outside of Tealand is Doom and Yoshi's Island, both rare and expensive.

Meanwhile the Dirt Trax FX and Stunt Race FX games can be had for $10-15 at times and there were tons of those. Yeah, it does suck to have to cannabalize older SNES games to make one of these, but there is no real way to create your own from scratch due to it being an FX game. No homebrew way to create your own FX chip. I mean, it can probably be implemented with a FPGA but I have zero clue how powerful (and thus expensive) an FPGA one would need. I tried to lookup the hardware in the FXPak but all I could find was that a prototype from 2011 used a Spartan 3 FPGA, no idea if the current carts also use that. Depending on the version they go from $18 to $120, most seem to be $18-40.

As for making it, many have made such a repro in the past. Most of them back then were made with the beta ROM that was floating around for years before the SNES Classic. Issue is with this having been done years ago, most guides are listing parts that are no longer easy to get (mostly the EEPROM) but if you know what you are doing you can use just about any viable EEPROM that's big enough and has the necessary pins.

When this came out it was amazing. Sleepovers me and my friends would stay up all night playing this. It was like the arcade in your house. It was such a huge leap above MKII, the gimmick was still fresh, and the graphics control and sound were just perfect.

MK3 changed the aesthetic, and I didn't like it when it came out, but playing them all over again, including the arcade versions (on the PS3), MK3 is the best classic MK. It's because of the combos and run button. MKII just feels so slow after playing it. Yeah it removed a lot of characters that were beloved in MK2, but Ultimate and Trilogy fixed that, along with adding new problems.

I'd seriously kill for a modern arcade quality MK Trilogy release. The PS1 and N64 versions have so many downsides.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I think people start looking at these games from a modern POV, one from during the era of widespread speed and skill runs. Remember that it has passwords - the intent was for the games to first be played over a period of time, not just to be speedrun fodder right off the bat. You see an item or seemingly unreachable passage and note it. Later, you happen to find an upgrade, and realize it could perhaps be used to snag something from one of those previously inaccessible areas. Sure, the helmet upgrade is cheesy, but once you have it and realize you're missing some upgrades, you go back through stages and fire it off randomly to see what it picks up. Sure, you might think it stupid and cumbersome, but again, even though the X games can be cleared 100% in sub-hour times, that wasn't the way they were intended to be played your first time through. Put yourself in the shoes of a kid who got the game in the 90s, and it was either a rental serving as the focus of an entire weekend's worth of dicking around, or a purchased or gifted game meant to hold you over for at least a few weeks until you could get something new.

Huh? In X, you just release the charge button and a giant shot comes out. Nothing wrong with it. The only downside is that, against some bosses, the max charge level causes the same damage as the level before.

In X2, perhaps there's some annoyance, since you have to wait for two shots to be fired. However, if it succeeds, you cause double damage, and, if you miss one of them, there's still the damage from the other one. Meanwhile, in X3, you have to fuse two crappy shots; if they don't mesh together, they become almost useless. Even if it succeeds, the damage isn't very worth. Also, if part of the (huge) shot is blocked, it can compromise the *whole* attack. In other words, there's seldom a good opportunity for using it.

Learn to appreciate things, fellas, don't miss out on good things life has to offer you just because you're a spoiled, grumpy kid

>>9605516
>I never hear about how "records and discs won't last forever" from music collectors, but people who collect games always parrot that shit.
I like to use car guys because they're the best example, but basically it's people who know about their hobby vs people who don't. For example most car guys know what's going on under their hood. If something happens to their dream car then they can usually pop the hood, investigate and figure out what the problem is, and repair it themselves. And if they don't know how then they'll reach out to people who do know how and ask for advice, learn how to fix it, and then get it done. But then when it comes to games, it seems that most gamers just play games and don't know anything about what's going on so when a problem arises they're shit out of luck. They don't know anything about the hardware so they just repeat whatever they heard in YouTube videos, which are made by people who also don't know about the hardware. All it takes is one Metal Jesus to say something stupid and everyone who watches them and also doesn't understand the hardware will repeat it forever because they trust the channel they watch much like boomers trust their favorite entertainment news channel.

In the coming years, more and more consoles will become in need of basic maintenance, and as that happens more and more casuals will probably turn to emulation because they're too scared to learn how to change a battery or a capacitor. My hope is that as a result of this, more and more retro gamers who play on physical hardware will become more like car guys and actually know what's going on under the hood. You don't have to be an expert, but you should be capable of basic repairs and upkeep and currently most people aren't. However, my fear is that during this transition period a lot of perfectly serviceable consoles (and maybe even games) will get trashed by retards because they're "broken."
